title: 112_hr718
content: The "Huntington's Disease Parity Act of 2011" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds that Huntington's Disease is a progressive neurological condition causing physical and mental deterioration in approximately 30,000 individuals in the US, with 200,000 more at genetic risk. There is currently no effective treatment to halt or slow the disease's progression, with clinical indicators including loss of movement control and cognitive impairment. Huntington's Disease affects 30,000 individuals in the US, with another 200,000 at genetic risk. There is no effective treatment to slow the disease's progression. Clinical indicators include loss of movement control, cognitive impairment, and behavioral changes. Adult-onset Huntington's Disease typically presents symptoms between 30 and 50 years of age, while late-onset occurs after 50 years with a milder course. Symptoms include memory loss, behavioral changes like irritability and depression, and cognitive issues such as inability to concentrate. Late-onset Huntington's Disease occurs after 50 years of age and is associated with a milder course. Juvenile Huntington's Disease affects individuals under 19 years old and progresses rapidly due to the incapacitating nature of the illness. Huntington's Disease affects individuals under 19 years old, progressing rapidly. Due to the incapacitating nature of the illness, affected individuals cannot work and rely on Social Security Disability Insurance. Despite medical advancements, the Social Security Administration has not updated its rules for evaluating neurological disabilities since 1985. The Social Security Administration has not updated its rules for evaluating neurological disabilities since 1985, leading individuals with Huntington's Disease to rely solely on Social Security Disability Insurance. The term "Huntington's Chorea" used by the Administration is outdated and medically inaccurate, failing to recognize the full impact of the disease. The Social Security Administration's use of "Huntington's Chorea" is outdated and inaccurate in describing Huntington's Disease, neglecting its behavioral and cognitive effects. Individuals with the disease face a 24-month wait for Medicare benefits after qualifying for Social Security Disability Insurance. After qualifying for Social Security Disability Insurance, individuals with Huntington's Disease must wait 24 months for Medicare benefits, despite often becoming incapacitated before the age-eligibility requirement of 65 years. In 2000, the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services waived the waiting period for ALS patients. In 2000, the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services waived the 24-month waiting period requirement for individuals disabled by ALS, a condition similar to Huntington's Disease. Due to the significant incapacitation faced by individuals with Huntington's Disease, there is an urgent need to update the Social Security Disability Insurance guidelines. Individuals with Huntington's Disease face significant cognitive, behavioral, and physical incapacitation, similar to ALS. There is an urgent need to revise the outdated Social Security Disability Insurance guidelines and remove the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage. The Social Security Administration needs to revise medical criteria for determining disability in individuals with Huntington's Disease and remove the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage, similar to ALS patients. The Social Security Administration is revising medical criteria for evaluating disability caused by adult-onset and juvenile Huntington's Disease. The Social Security Administration is updating medical criteria for assessing disability due to Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease in consultation with medical experts. The Social Security Administration is updating medical criteria for assessing disability due to Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease with input from medical experts. This includes amending sections 11.00 and 12.00 of the Listing of Impairments to provide medical and evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease. The Social Security Administration is updating medical criteria for assessing disability due to Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease by amending sections of the Listing of Impairments to provide medical and evaluation criteria for the disease. The Social Security Administration is updating medical criteria for assessing disability due to Juvenile Huntington's Disease by amending sections of the Listing of Impairments to provide medical and evaluation criteria for the disease. The amendments include criteria for neurological and mental disorders in children affected by Juvenile Huntington's Disease. The Social Security Act is amended to waive the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage for individuals diagnosed with Huntington's Disease. This amendment applies to benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act for items and services provided after the enactment of the Act.
